paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted information on the TTR gene variants, including penetrance data and individual records.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Polyneuropathy with sensorimotor and autonomic disturbances
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The most common mutation is a single-nucleotide substitution that causes the substitution of Valine in position 30 with Methionine (ATTR Val30Met).
The association of altered TTR makes amyloid fibrils and leads to the formation of amyloid plaques in numerous organs such as the peripheral nerves, heart, kidneys, and gastrointestinal tract.

functional_data.summary: The TTR protein binds and transports thyroxine and retinol, and mutations lead to amyloid fibril formation.
assays: In vitro studies on TTR protein stability
Functional assays on amyloid fibril formation

variants.segregation_data: Segregates with disease in families, as seen in clinical trials.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence from clinical trials and patient data.
variants.additional_notes: The TTR gene is implicated in hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis, a life-threatening disease.
key_quotes: hATTR is a rare autosomal dominant, multisystemic, progressive disease caused by more than 120 mutations in the gene encoding transthyretin (TTR).
Patients that received inotersen obtained an improvement of their life’s quality.

extraction_metadata.notes: Data was extracted thoroughly from the main text.
